title: Assessment Framework at the End of Key Stage 1: Mathematics
subject: Mathematics

document.title: Interim teacher assessment frameworks at the end of key stage 1

A8019A36503642D29BB669E91250D424.description:
describe similarities and differences of shape properties (e.g. finds 2 different 2-D shapes that only have one line of symmetry;
that a cube and a cuboid have the same number of edges, faces and vertices but can describe what is different about them)

29C9C628BEA74F3493651AF606397219.description: read scales in divisions of ones, twos, fives and tens in a practical situation where not all numbers on the scale are given

005E339036B74BD38C45708B50F6F178.description: read the time on the clock to the nearest 5 minutes

60A2F29F4C6448A7A23349A4C0BA29C3.description:
find and compare fractions of amounts
(e.g. 1/4 of £20 = £5 and 1/2 of £8 = £4 so 1/4 of £20 is greater than 1/2 of £8)

9D8F2130A1C7422E82CDDFBDDBF8E7A9.description:
recognise the relationships between addition and subtraction and can rewrite addition statements as simplified multiplication statements
(e.g. 10 + 10 + 10 + 5 + 5 = 3 × 10 + 2 × 5 = 4 × 10)

262ACE5E5B5F421BA4AEF862125B93B0.description:
solve word problems that involve more than one step
(e.g. which has the most biscuits, 4 packets of biscuits with 5 in each packet or 3 packets of biscuits with 10 in each packet?)

37A7DE121918425D8F008A81FC26A507.description:
determine remainders given known facts
(e.g. given 15 ÷ 5 = 3 and has a remainder of 0, pupil recognises that 16 ÷ 5 will have a remainder of 1; knowing that 2 × 7 = 14 and 2 × 8 = 16, pupil explains that making pairs of socks from 15 identical socks will give 7 pairs and one sock will be left)

CEC430FDA1E94C0788FB4D2EDE3B76D3.description: solve more complex missing number problems (e.g. 14 + ∆  – 3 = 17; 14 + ∆ = 15 + 27)

745DAF1AF7AA4B619F5A7826F3C36BBD.description: work out mental calculations where regrouping is required (e.g. 52 − 27; 91 – 73)

F221F981F2EA47509518706F2ED6A4B9.description: use multiplication facts to make deductions outside known multiplication facts (e.g. a pupil knows that multiples of 5 have one digit of 0 or 5 and uses this to reason that 18 × 5 cannot be 92 as it is not a multiple of 5)

C99F40556D2C4425A21E06261F51FA1F.description:
reason about addition
(e.g. pupil can reason that the sum of 3 odd numbers will always be odd)

F7C4AF09B9D64E14A8541BD1B23A9175.description: Working at greater depth within the expected standard

943A49AC48D5433CAFB7E55E8A1C93DA.description:
describe properties of 2-D and 3-D shapes (e.g. the pupil describes a triangle: it has 3 sides, 3 vertices and 1 line of symmetry;
the pupil describes a pyramid: it has 8 edges, 5 faces, 4 of which are triangles and one is a square)

4B052E7B33F746F99D49E21C33B40E4B.description: read the time on the clock to the nearest 15 minutes

7CB8B48CE172474896CE3C7F91896B14.description:
read scales in divisions of ones, twos, fives and tens in a practical situation where all numbers on the scale are given
(e.g. pupil reads the temperature on a thermometer or measures capacities using
a measuring jug)

2CBA2C21FC1C4C1EA0E62ED233E472D5.description: use different coins to make the same amount (e.g. pupil uses coins to make 50p in different ways; pupil can work out how many £2 coins are needed to exchange for a £20 note)

59B54479F2A64D7B9CB7732F0E504FD4.description: identify 1/3 , 1/4 , 1/2 , 2/4 , 3/4 and knows that all parts must be equal parts of the whole

9530FCF00AEA423088E2E497C05B4660.description:
recognise the inverse relationships between addition and subtraction and use this to check calculations and work out missing number problems
(e.g. ∆ − 14 = 28)

CD501080D51248D8911880E86262438C.description: subtract mentally a two-digit number from another two-digit number when there is no regrouping required (e.g. 74 − 33)

7039835FE1574230A66694AC7AE24632.description: use estimation to check that their answers to a calculation are reasonable (e.g. knowing that 48 + 35 will be less than 100)

E91ECA5AFB234590886D66A36762F246.description: add 2 two-digit numbers within 100 (e.g. 48 + 35) and can demonstrate their method using concrete apparatus or pictorial representations

D932264855F44928A98C22B1AE801621.description: partition two-digit numbers into di erent combinations of tens and ones. This may include using apparatus (e.g. 23 is the same as 2 tens and 3 ones which is the same as 1 ten and 13 ones)

06BBD66ABF8E4E48B0B4714F61BA239B.description: recognise and name triangles, rectangles, squares, circles, cuboids, cubes, pyramids and spheres from a group of shapes or from pictures of the shapes

12C89896BD454D08AA5B3E667243C0E2.description:
recall doubles and halves to 20
(e.g. pupil knows that double 2 is 4, double 5 is 10 and half of 18 is 9)

4846926E9A56484998404ABCFA5C290A.description: add and subtract a two-digit number and ones and a two-digit number and tens where no regrouping is required (e.g. 23 + 5; 46 + 20), they can demonstrate their method using concrete apparatus or pictorial representations

CD0CDAC56A494B81A2A8914D9C01111A.description: use number bonds and related subtraction facts within 20 (e.g. 18 = 9 + ?; 15 = 6 + ?)

645A78C8D25443C7B12AC44551B57C2D.description: read and write numbers correctly in numerals up to 100 (e.g. can write the numbers 14 and 41 correctly)

E1EFC12402F6472982392813963AFFD5.description: count in twos, fives and tens from 0 and use counting strategies to solve problems (e.g. count the number of chairs in a diagram when the chairs are organised in 7 rows of 5 by counting in fives)

BE51AEFCC5F540F2AF3A9A8FB753C0AA.description:
demonstrate an understanding of place value, though may still need to use apparatus to support them
(e.g. by stating the difference in the tens and ones between 2 numbers i.e. 77 and 33 has a difference of 40 for the tens and a difference of 4 for the ones; by writing number statements such as 35 < 53 and 42 > 36)

1DBC13C96CFF4EB3BC3CC9275E9F6A09.description: put up to 20 items into groups of 2 or 5 or into 2 or 5 equal groups (e.g. give the pupil 5 hoops and 15 objects and ask them to share them equally between the hoops)

4B7D034DF5544AC284EDF6002469C8F3.description: solve problems involving the addition and subtraction of single digit numbers up to 10

B33439B03A734165902A08D0C8E63D9F.description:
The pupil can use number bonds from 1 to 5 (e.g. partitioning the number 5 as 0+5, 1+4, 2+3, 3 + 2,
4 + 1, 5 + 0; use concrete objects to demonstrate the commutative law and inverse relationships involving addition and subtraction e.g. 3 + 2 = 5, therefore 2 + 3 = 5 and 5 – 3 = 2 and 5 – 2 = 3)

AED76B6B3071458FB26EC75B9827C86C.description: read and write numerals from 0 to 9 and demonstrate an understanding of the mathematical symbols of add, subtract and equal to

573C043FAB294CEA9C672B8F9836598E.description:
count forwards and back from 0 to 20, understanding that numbers increase
and decrease in size and identify a number that is one more or one less than a given number (e.g. identify missing numbers on a number scale from 0 to 20)

4760A110075042D0AC8907201E26A60F.description: demonstrate an understanding of place value of 10s and 1s in a two digit number, using resources to support them if necessary (e.g. representing a two digit number using resources for tens and ones; comparing two numbers up to 20 to identify the larger and smaller number without apparatus)
